post.author: bpanjavan
post.title: Programming is Like Playing a Musical Instrument. Actually...
post.content:
vs. 

Programming is Like Playing a Musical Instrument.  Actually...

I'm a fan of Jeff Atwood, the man for whom inspired me to start my own blog.  A January 2009 post opens up this gate of discussion:

http://www.codinghorror.com/blog/archives/001214.html

In this post he makes the conclusion "I worry that this is just another convenient, self-fulfilling analogy we programmers use to puff ourselves up".

I understand.  By definition an analogy does NOT have to be perfect.  Correct me if I'm mistaken but I think a so-called "perfect analogy" would no longer be an analogy, but rather an equivalency!

I've been playing the piano since I was 6 years old.  Actually, it's more like I started when I was 6 under strict training, played recitals, attended workshops, learned history and theory, stopped when I was 12, used my experience to play the piano in my high school Jazz Band, stopped again, played whenever I felt like it, but in the end it was like riding a bicycle.  I never forgot and I'm once again picking it up as a hobby.

My experience leads me to believe that the assertion "Programming is like playing a musical instrument" may not be too deep, but this one goes deeper:

"Software Development is like Performing Music"

I feel it's only right that I be concrete with specific comparative analysis.  Here are the results of my wishful thinking:

1. Keeping your skills up-to-date:
 - It's easy to keep playing the songs in your repertoire.  I can think of maybe 20 that I'll play over and over again because they stick with me.  If you want to keep your skills up, you MUST keep progressing and learning new songs, maybe even new styles.
 
Coding is no different.  How many times can you keep binding a Gridview, or retrieving DataSets through ADO.NET while still keeping it new?  To keep programming is just not enough.  There are always newer things to do.

2. Requirements Gathering and Estimates
 - I'm learning a new song that I wanted to play for my wife.  It's about 8 pages long and didn't seem too complex.  I told her it would take about 2 weeks if I kept at it.  That's about 2 days per page, which doesn't sound difficult.  But of course unexpected things happen.  Counting the eighth notes per measure was more difficult than I thought.  There were some portions where the key signature would change and those sections were more difficult.  I should've doubled my initial estimate.
 
In Software Development, we try hard to come up with accurate estimates.  But there are things that are too difficult to predict.  In my current project we're experiencing difficulty with loading all of our new data into Staging, which is delaying our Go-Live date.  Who could've known??  BA's can still come to you with things that just "slipped through the cracks".  There's really no such thing as 100% full proof requirements gathering and likewise no such perfect estimates.

3.  Some Tasks are Never Really Done
Another reason why it is taking me slower than expected is because I'm spending more time on certain pages than I had originally planned.  Not because I'm not done learning them, but because I can't help it.  I want to keep going back over the pages I've learned to make sure I can still play them well enough, to make sure they are refined if they need to be.

It's not such a bad habit.  But on a project you have a tendency to keep going back over the code you've written, even though the task is supposedly "done".  Maybe you feel there's something more you should add, or better, something you can take away.  Maybe you want to do just one more dry-run to make sure your code is working correctly.

4.  Testing
It's never enough for me to test myself and feel that I'm good enough.  Growing up it was my professional instructor that had to listen to what I had learned so far and hear me play.  Only she could notice things that I simply didn't notice when I was listening to myself.  More importantly, I could be playing a note wrong without ever noticing it until someone else points it out.

In addition to the "second set of eyes" principle, this emphasizes early and ongoing user testing.  Someone has to constantly be using your application as a sanity check because you know you won't find every nuance yourself.

5. Going Live With Imperfection
If I had an upcoming recital, it didn't matter how ready I was.  I'm going to play.  I may still be having a little trouble on the second page.  I might be over-crescendoing on the coda, but it doesn't matter.  When  it's time to Go-Live, I need to be ready.  The exception is if I'm SO un-prepared that I can't even get through the song.

Sometimes the schedule is so important that when things have to be "done", you have to "finish" them.  Buggy and imperfect software that works is often good enough to Go-Live.  You know the consequences.  The software is not as good as it could've been if you just spent one more month on refinement.  But that's good enough.  The exception is if the software just doesn't work.

That's 5 ways I can think of in which "Software Development is like Performing Music"...

comment.author: &amp;#1502;&amp;#1508;&amp;#1506;&amp;#1500; &amp;#1492;&amp;#1508;&amp;#1497;&amp;#1497;&amp;#1505;
comment.content: 10 regular smokers were selected for the study. They were given a cycle each and asked to pedal at moderate speed, after they were abstained from nicotine intake for 15 hours. Then they were given FMRI (which refers to Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scans as they were shown 60 images. Among those pictures were some showing cigarettes to stimulate the craving in smokers. The next study was done on the same 10 people. They were given the same FMRI scan and the same photos were shown to them again. The brain images that were captured during both the studies show a substantial difference. In the second scan reports, patients display signs that indicated they craved for a smoke.

comment.content: Perhaps no other sports collectible is as revered as the cigarette baseball cards produced in the late 18th and early 19th century. Still striking in appearance, even today, these vintage cards were landmark at the time of issue and considered the gold standard among today's sports card collectors.
